title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: jsurvival provides comprehensive survival analysis tools specifically designed clinical research oncology studies. module offers user-friendly interfaces time--event analysis, basic Kaplan-Meier curves advanced competing risks multivariate Cox regression models. Learning Objectives: Master fundamental survival analysis concepts methods Learn Kaplan-Meier survival curve construction interpretation Apply Cox proportional hazards regression multivariable analysis Understand competing risks analysis complex clinical scenarios Implement molecular biomarker survival analysis workflows Create publication-ready survival plots tables

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: jsurvival encompasses four main areas survival analysis:

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Kaplan-Meier Curves: Non-parametric survival estimation Log-rank Tests: Compare survival groups Median Survival: Time--event summary statistics Confidence Intervals: Uncertainty quantification survival estimates

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Cox Proportional Hazards: Multivariable time--event modeling Stratified Cox Models: Account non-proportional hazards Time-dependent Covariates: Dynamic risk factor modeling Model Diagnostics: Assumption testing validation

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Competing Risks: Multiple event types analysis Multistate Models: Disease progression modeling Parametric Survival: Weibull, exponential, distributions Frailty Models: Unobserved heterogeneity modeling

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Biomarker Analysis: Molecular predictor evaluation Treatment Comparisons: Therapeutic intervention assessment Prognostic Models: Risk stratification tools Real-World Evidence: Population-based survival studies
code: library(jsurvival) library(survival) library(dplyr)

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
code:
# Load molecular pathology survival data data(ihc_molecular_comprehensive)  # Survival data structure cat("Survival dataset dimensions:", nrow(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "×", ncol(ihc_molecular_comprehensive), "
")  # Key survival variables survival_vars <- c("Overall_Survival_Months", "Death_Event", "PFS_Months", "Progression_Event") cat("Survival variables:", paste(survival_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Molecular biomarkers for stratification biomarker_vars <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC", "PD_L1_TPS") cat("Biomarker variables:", paste(biomarker_vars, collapse = ", "), "
")  # Basic survival summary survival_summary <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     median_os = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     death_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),     median_pfs = median(PFS_Months),     progression_rate = round(mean(Progression_Event) * 100, 1)   )  cat("
Survival Summary:
") cat("Patients:", survival_summary$n, "
") cat("Median OS:", survival_summary$median_os, "months
") cat("Death rate:", survival_summary$death_rate, "%
") cat("Median PFS:", survival_summary$median_pfs, "months
") cat("Progression rate:", survival_summary$progression_rate, "%
")

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Foundation survival analysis time--event data.
code:
# Kaplan-Meier Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Survival Analysis  cat("Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis
") cat("==============================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(survival)      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Overall survival curve   km_overall <- survfit(surv_obj ~ 1, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Overall Survival Analysis:
")   print(summary(km_overall, times = c(12, 24, 36, 60))$table)      # Survival by EGFR mutation status   km_egfr <- survfit(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("
Survival by EGFR Status:
")   egfr_summary <- summary(km_egfr)$table   print(egfr_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_egfr <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ EGFR_Mutation, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_egfr$chisq, 1)      cat("
Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: No significant difference in survival by EGFR status
")   } }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Multivariable analysis accounting multiple prognostic factors.
code:
# Cox Regression Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Cox Diagnostics  cat("
Cox Proportional Hazards Regression
") cat("===================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Multivariable Cox model   cox_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                       EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status + Age + Grade + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                      data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      cat("Cox Regression Results:
")   cox_summary <- summary(cox_model)   print(cox_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance:", round(cox_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("R-squared:", round(cox_summary$rsq[1], 3), "
")   cat("Likelihood ratio test p-value:", round(cox_summary$logtest[3], 4), "
")      # Hazard ratios with confidence intervals   cat("
Hazard Ratios (95% CI):
")   hr_ci <- exp(confint(cox_model))   hr_estimates <- exp(cox_model$coefficients)      for(i in 1:length(hr_estimates)) {     var_name <- names(hr_estimates)[i]     hr <- round(hr_estimates[i], 2)     ci_lower <- round(hr_ci[i, 1], 2)     ci_upper <- round(hr_ci[i, 2], 2)     p_val <- round(cox_summary$coefficients[i, "Pr(>|z|)"], 3)          cat(paste0(var_name, ": HR = ", hr, " (", ci_lower, "-", ci_upper, "), p = ", p_val, "
"))   } }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Handle situations multiple types events can occur.
code:
# Competing Risks Analysis Example # In jamovi: jsurvival > Competing Survival  cat("
Competing Risks Analysis
") cat("=======================

")  # Create competing events data # Death from disease vs death from other causes competing_data <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     # Simulate competing events     death_cause = case_when(       Death_Event == 0 ~ "Alive",       Death_Event == 1 & Grade == 3 ~ "Disease",       Death_Event == 1 & Age > 75 ~ "Other",       Death_Event == 1 ~ sample(c("Disease", "Other"), 1, prob = c(0.7, 0.3)),       TRUE ~ "Alive"     ),          # Competing event indicator     event_type = case_when(       death_cause == "Disease" ~ 1,       death_cause == "Other" ~ 2,       TRUE ~ 0     )   )  # Competing risks summary competing_summary <- competing_data %>%   group_by(death_cause) %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     percentage = round(n() / nrow(competing_data) * 100, 1),     median_time = median(Overall_Survival_Months),     .groups = 'drop'   )  cat("Competing Events Summary:
") print(competing_summary)  # Event rates by biomarker status biomarker_events <- competing_data %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation, death_cause) %>%   summarise(n = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>%   group_by(EGFR_Mutation) %>%   mutate(percentage = round(n / sum(n) * 100, 1))  cat("
Event Rates by EGFR Status:
") print(biomarker_events)  # Clinical interpretation disease_death_rate <- mean(competing_data$death_cause == "Disease") * 100 cat("
Clinical Interpretation:
") cat("Disease-specific death rate:", round(disease_death_rate, 1), "%
")  if(disease_death_rate > 50) {   cat("Conclusion: Disease is the predominant cause of death
") } else {   cat("Conclusion: Competing causes of death are significant
") }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate prognostic impact molecular biomarkers.
code:
cat("Molecular Biomarker Survival Analysis
") cat("====================================

")  # Multiple biomarker analysis biomarkers <- c("EGFR_Mutation", "MSI_Status", "HER2_IHC")  for(biomarker in biomarkers) {   cat(paste0("Survival Analysis for ", biomarker, ":
"))   cat(paste0(rep("-", nchar(biomarker) + 25), collapse = ""), "
")      # Create survival object   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      # Survival by biomarker   formula_str <- paste("surv_obj ~", biomarker)   km_biomarker <- survfit(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Summary statistics   biomarker_summary <- summary(km_biomarker)$table   print(biomarker_summary)      # Log-rank test   logrank_test <- survdiff(as.formula(formula_str), data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   p_value <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_test$chisq, length(unique(ihc_molecular_comprehensive[[biomarker]])) - 1)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value, 4), "
")      if(p_value < 0.05) {     cat("Result: Significant prognostic biomarker
")   } else {     cat("Result: Not a significant prognostic biomarker
")   }   cat("
") }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Evaluate continuous biomarkers like PD-L1 expression tumor mutational burden.
code:
cat("Continuous Biomarker Analysis
") cat("=============================

")  # PD-L1 TPS analysis pdl1_quartiles <- quantile(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$PD_L1_TPS,                            probs = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0))  ihc_with_quartiles <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%   mutate(     PD_L1_Quartile = cut(PD_L1_TPS,                          breaks = pdl1_quartiles,                         labels = c("Q1 (Low)", "Q2", "Q3", "Q4 (High)"),                         include.lowest = TRUE),          PD_L1_Clinical = case_when(       PD_L1_TPS < 1 ~ "Negative (<1%)",       PD_L1_TPS < 50 ~ "Low Positive (1-49%)",       TRUE ~ "High Positive (≥50%)"     )   )  cat("PD-L1 TPS Distribution:
") pdl1_dist <- table(ihc_with_quartiles$PD_L1_Clinical) print(pdl1_dist)  # Survival by PD-L1 clinical categories if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   surv_obj <- Surv(ihc_with_quartiles$Overall_Survival_Months,                    ihc_with_quartiles$Death_Event)      km_pdl1 <- survfit(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)      cat("
Survival by PD-L1 Expression Level:
")   pdl1_summary <- summary(km_pdl1)$table   print(pdl1_summary)      # Test for trend   logrank_pdl1 <- survdiff(surv_obj ~ PD_L1_Clinical, data = ihc_with_quartiles)   p_value_pdl1 <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_pdl1$chisq, 2)      cat("Log-rank test p-value:", round(p_value_pdl1, 4), "
")      # Tumor mutational burden analysis   tmb_median <- median(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden)   tmb_high <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Tumor_Mutational_Burden >= tmb_median      cat("
Tumor Mutational Burden Analysis:
")   cat("Median TMB:", tmb_median, "mutations/Mb
")   cat("TMB-High cases:", sum(tmb_high), "(", round(mean(tmb_high) * 100, 1), "%)
")      # TMB survival analysis   km_tmb <- survfit(surv_obj ~ tmb_high, data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)   tmb_summary <- summary(km_tmb)$table      cat("Survival by TMB Status:
")   print(tmb_summary) }

title: jSurvival 01: Introduction to Survival Analysis for Pathologists
text: Develop comprehensive prognostic models incorporating multiple biomarkers.
code:
cat("Multivariable Prognostic Model Development
") cat("=========================================

")  if(requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Comprehensive prognostic model   prog_model <- coxph(Surv(Overall_Survival_Months, Death_Event) ~                        Age + Grade +                        EGFR_Mutation + MSI_Status +                        PD_L1_TPS + Tumor_Mutational_Burden,                       data = ihc_molecular_comprehensive)      # Model summary   prog_summary <- summary(prog_model)      cat("Comprehensive Prognostic Model:
")   print(prog_summary$coefficients[, c("coef", "exp(coef)", "Pr(>|z|)")])      # Model performance metrics   cat("
Model Performance:
")   cat("Concordance index:", round(prog_summary$concordance[1], 3), "
")   cat("Standard error:", round(prog_summary$concordance[2], 3), "
")      # Risk score calculation   risk_scores <- predict(prog_model, type = "risk")   risk_tertiles <- cut(risk_scores,                        breaks = quantile(risk_scores, probs = c(0, 1/3, 2/3, 1)),                       labels = c("Low Risk", "Intermediate Risk", "High Risk"),                       include.lowest = TRUE)      # Risk group validation   risk_validation <- ihc_molecular_comprehensive %>%     mutate(Risk_Group = risk_tertiles) %>%     group_by(Risk_Group) %>%     summarise(       n = n(),       events = sum(Death_Event),       event_rate = round(mean(Death_Event) * 100, 1),       median_survival = median(Overall_Survival_Months),       .groups = 'drop'     )      cat("
Risk Group Validation:
")   print(risk_validation)      # Test risk stratification   surv_risk <- Surv(ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Overall_Survival_Months,                     ihc_molecular_comprehensive$Death_Event)      km_risk <- survfit(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   logrank_risk <- survdiff(surv_risk ~ risk_tertiles)   p_value_risk <- 1 - pchisq(logrank_risk$chisq, 2)      cat("Risk stratification p-value:", round(p_value_risk, 4), "
")      if(p_value_risk < 0.001) {     cat("Conclusion: Excellent risk stratification achieved
")   } else if(p_value_risk < 0.05) {     cat("Conclusion: Significant risk stratification achieved
")   } else {     cat("Conclusion: Risk stratification needs improvement
")   } }

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: Time-dependent covariates variables change values course follow-time. clinical research, many important variables can change study period, : Treatment regimens (switching standard experimental therapy) Disease status (remission, progression) Performance status Biomarker levels Comorbidities multisurvival function ClinicoPath now supports time-dependent covariates wide long data formats, making easier analyze survival data covariates change time.

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: wide format, subject one row, time-dependent variables represented separate columns different time points.

previous_headings: Data Format Options > Wide Format Data
title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: Wide Format Advantages: - One row per patient (easier understand) - Common format clinical databases - Easy create existing data Wide Format Requirements: - Baseline variables: variable_baseline just variable - Time-specific variables: variable_t6, variable_t12, etc. - Change times specified options
code: # Example wide format data structure wide_data <- data.frame(   id = 1:3,   age = c(65, 72, 58),   sex = factor(c("Male", "Female", "Male")),   time = c(24, 18, 30),   status = c(1, 0, 1),      # Baseline treatment (time 0)   treatment_baseline = factor(c("Standard", "Standard", "Experimental")),      # Treatment at 6 months   treatment_t6 = factor(c("Standard", "Experimental", "Experimental")),      # Treatment at 12 months     treatment_t12 = factor(c("Experimental", "Experimental", "Stopped")),      # Treatment at 18 months   treatment_t18 = factor(c("Experimental", "Stopped", "Stopped")) )  print(wide_data) ##   id age    sex time status treatment_baseline treatment_t6 treatment_t12 ## 1  1  65   Male   24      1           Standard     Standard  Experimental ## 2  2  72 Female   18      0           Standard Experimental  Experimental ## 3  3  58   Male   30      1       Experimental Experimental       Stopped ##   treatment_t18 ## 1  Experimental ## 2       Stopped ## 3       Stopped

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: long format, subject can multiple rows, one row time interval covariates remain constant.

previous_headings: Data Format Options > Long Format Data
title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: Long Format Advantages: - flexible complex time patterns - Standard format survival analysis packages - Can handle irregular time intervals Long Format Requirements: - tstart tstop variables time intervals - Status = 1 final interval event occurs - Time-dependent variables change rows
code: # Example long format data structure   long_data <- data.frame(   id = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3),   age = c(65, 65, 65, 72, 72, 58, 58),   sex = factor(c("Male", "Male", "Male", "Female", "Female", "Male", "Male")),   tstart = c(0, 6, 12, 0, 6, 0, 12),   tstop = c(6, 12, 24, 6, 18, 12, 30),   status = c(0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1),   treatment = factor(c("Standard", "Standard", "Experimental",                        "Standard", "Experimental", "Experimental", "Stopped")) )  print(long_data) ##   id age    sex tstart tstop status    treatment ## 1  1  65   Male      0     6      0     Standard ## 2  1  65   Male      6    12      0     Standard ## 3  1  65   Male     12    24      1 Experimental ## 4  2  72 Female      0     6      0     Standard ## 5  2  72 Female      6    18      0 Experimental ## 6  3  58   Male      0    12      0 Experimental ## 7  3  58   Male     12    30      1      Stopped

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: library(jsurvival)  # Load example wide format data load("test_wide_time_dependent.rda")  result <- multisurvival(   data = test_wide_time_dependent,   elapsedtime = "time",   outcome = "status",    outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = c("sex", "stage"),   contexpl = "age",      # Time-dependent covariate options   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",   time_dep_vars = c("treatment_baseline"),  # Base variable name   change_times = "6, 12, 18",               # When changes occur   td_suffix_pattern = "_t{time}",           # Naming pattern      timetypeoutput = "months" )

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: # Load example long format data load("test_long_time_dependent.rda")  result <- multisurvival(   data = test_long_time_dependent,      # No elapsedtime needed - using tstart/tstop   outcome = "status",   outcomeLevel = "1",    explanatory = c("sex", "stage"),   contexpl = "age",      # Time-dependent covariate options   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "long",    start_time_var = "tstart",   stop_time_var = "tstop",   time_dep_vars = c("treatment"),  # Time-varying variable      timetypeoutput = "months" )

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: # Wide format with multiple time-dependent variables result <- multisurvival(   data = clinical_data,   elapsedtime = "followup_months",   outcome = "event_status",   outcomeLevel = "Event",   explanatory = c("sex", "initial_stage"),   contexpl = "baseline_age",      # Multiple time-dependent variables   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",   time_dep_vars = c("treatment_baseline", "ps_baseline"),  # Multiple variables   change_times = "3, 6, 12, 18",           # More frequent assessments   td_suffix_pattern = "_month{time}",       # Different naming pattern      # Additional analysis options   calculateRiskScore = TRUE,   numRiskGroups = "three",   hr = TRUE )

what: Combining Time-Dependent Covariates with Other Features
title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: # Complex analysis with multiple advanced features result <- multisurvival(   data = oncology_data,   elapsedtime = "survival_months",    outcome = "vital_status",   outcomeLevel = "Dead",   explanatory = c("histology", "grade"),   contexpl = c("age_at_diagnosis", "tumor_size"),      # Time-dependent covariates   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",   time_dep_vars = c("treatment_baseline", "response_baseline"),   change_times = "6, 12, 24",   td_suffix_pattern = "_m{time}",      # Frailty model for hospital clustering   use_frailty = TRUE,   frailty_var = "treatment_center",   frailty_distribution = "gamma",      # Splines for non-proportional hazards   use_splines = TRUE,   spline_vars = "age_at_diagnosis",   spline_df = 3,   spline_type = "pspline",      # Model selection   use_modelSelection = TRUE,   modelSelection = "backward",   selectionCriteria = "aic",      # Risk stratification   calculateRiskScore = TRUE,   numRiskGroups = "four",   plotRiskGroups = TRUE )

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: # Example conversion from long to wide format library(dplyr) library(tidyr)  # Starting with long format data long_format <- data.frame(   patient_id = c(rep(1, 3), rep(2, 2), rep(3, 4)),   visit_month = c(0, 6, 12, 0, 6, 0, 6, 12, 18),   treatment = c("A", "A", "B", "A", "B", "A", "A", "A", "B"),   performance_status = c(0, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 2) )  # Convert to wide format wide_format <- long_format %>%   pivot_wider(     id_cols = patient_id,     names_from = visit_month,     values_from = c(treatment, performance_status),     names_sep = "_t"   ) %>%   # Rename baseline variables   rename(     treatment_baseline = treatment_t0,     ps_baseline = performance_status_t0   )

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: Time-dependent covariates particularly useful oncology:
code: # Analyze impact of treatment switching in cancer patients cancer_analysis <- multisurvival(   data = cancer_cohort,   elapsedtime = "overall_survival_months",   outcome = "death_status",    outcomeLevel = "Dead",   explanatory = c("cancer_type", "stage_at_diagnosis"),   contexpl = c("age_at_diagnosis", "baseline_performance_status"),      # Treatment changes over time   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",   time_dep_vars = c("primary_treatment_baseline"),   change_times = "3, 6, 12, 18, 24",  # Quarterly assessments   td_suffix_pattern = "_quarter{time}",      # Account for treatment center effects   use_frailty = TRUE,   frailty_var = "treatment_center",      # Test proportional hazards assumption   ph_cox = TRUE,      # Generate comprehensive outputs   hr = TRUE,   calculateRiskScore = TRUE,   person_time = TRUE )

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
code: # Analyze changing cardiovascular risk factors cv_analysis <- multisurvival(   data = cardiovascular_study,   tint = TRUE,   dxdate = "enrollment_date",   fudate = "last_contact_date",   timetypedata = "ymd",   timetypeoutput = "years",   outcome = "cv_event",   outcomeLevel = "Yes",   explanatory = c("gender", "diabetes_baseline"),   contexpl = c("baseline_age", "baseline_bmi"),      # Time-varying medication and lab values   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",    time_dep_vars = c("statin_use_baseline", "bp_medication_baseline"),   change_times = "0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5",  # Annual visits   td_suffix_pattern = "_year{time}",      # Account for clinic clustering   use_frailty = TRUE,   frailty_var = "clinic_id",   frailty_distribution = "gamma" )

Causality: Time-dependent covariates help address time-varying confounding don’t guarantee causal interpretation.

title: Time-Dependent Covariates in Multisurvival Analysis
text: Time-dependent covariates work seamlessly advanced features:
code: # Comprehensive analysis combining all advanced features comprehensive_analysis <- multisurvival(   data = complex_dataset,   elapsedtime = "time_to_event",   outcome = "event_indicator",   outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = c("treatment_arm", "biomarker_status"),   contexpl = c("age", "baseline_score"),      # Time-dependent covariates   use_time_dependent = TRUE,   td_format = "wide",   time_dep_vars = c("drug_dose_baseline", "toxicity_grade_baseline"),   change_times = "4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24",      # Frailty for center effects   use_frailty = TRUE,   frailty_var = "study_center",   frailty_distribution = "gamma",      # Splines for non-linear age effects   use_splines = TRUE,   spline_vars = "age",   spline_df = 4,   spline_type = "ns",      # Stratification for non-proportional hazards   use_stratify = TRUE,   stratvar = "biomarker_status",      # Model selection   use_modelSelection = TRUE,   modelSelection = "both",   selectionCriteria = "aic",      # Risk assessment   calculateRiskScore = TRUE,   numRiskGroups = "four",   plotRiskGroups = TRUE,      # Comprehensive outputs   hr = TRUE,   km = TRUE,   ac = TRUE,   adjexplanatory = "treatment_arm",   person_time = TRUE,   ph_cox = TRUE,   showNomogram = TRUE )

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time analysis fundamental concept epidemiology survival analysis accounts varying observation periods study participants. jsurvival module ClinicoPath provides comprehensive person-time calculations incidence rate analysis across survival analysis functions.

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Person-time represents total observation time contributed participants study risk event interest. Unlike simple participant counts, person-time captures number subjects observation duration, providing accurate denominators rate calculations.

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Total Person-Time: Sum individual follow-periods Incidence Rate: Number events ÷ Total person-time Time Units: Typically expressed person-days, person-months, person-years Censoring: Properly accounts participants leaving study early Varying Follow-: Handles different observation periods participant

title: Person-Time Analysis in jsurvival Module
text: Accurate Rate Calculations: Provides proper denominators incidence rates Comparison Across Studies: Enables valid comparisons populations different follow-patterns Adjustment Time: Accounts varying exposure periods survival analysis Kaplan-Meier Foundation: Forms basis survival curve estimation Cox Model Integration: Essential hazard ratio calculations

title: Clinical Research Examples with jsurvival
text: Interpretation: - Separate hazard ratios cancer-specific -cause mortality - Treatment effects may differ competing outcomes - Consider cumulative incidence functions formal competing risk analysis
code: # For competing risks, use cause-specific outcomes # Death_cancer: 1 = cancer death, 0 = alive or other death # Death_other: 1 = other death, 0 = alive or cancer death  # Cancer-specific survival analysis cancer_specific <- survival(   data = competing_data,   elapsedtime = OS_months,   outcome = Death_cancer,   outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = Treatment,   analysistype = "overall",   ph_cox = TRUE )  # Other-cause mortality analysis other_cause <- survival(   data = competing_data,   elapsedtime = OS_months,   outcome = Death_other,   outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = Treatment,   analysistype = "overall",   ph_cox = TRUE )

title: Clinical Research Examples with jsurvival
text: Key Points: - includes patients survived landmark time - Eliminates guarantee-time bias - Useful post-treatment predictors
code: # Create landmark dataset (patients alive at 3 months) landmark_data <- subset(original_data, OS_months > 3 | (OS_months <= 3 & Death == 0))  # Adjust survival times for landmark point landmark_data$OS_months_landmark <- landmark_data$OS_months - 3 landmark_data$OS_months_landmark[landmark_data$OS_months_landmark < 0] <- 0  # Analyze survival from landmark time landmark_result <- survival(   data = landmark_data,   elapsedtime = OS_months_landmark,   outcome = Death,   outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = Response_3month,   uselandmark = TRUE,   landmark = 3 )

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Rogers phenomenon statistical paradox occurs medicine patients reclassified disease stages due improvements diagnostic technology changes staging criteria. phenomenon gets name humorous quote attributed American humorist Rogers: “Okies left Oklahoma moved California, raised average intelligence level states.” pathology oncology, phenomenon particularly relevant analyzing impact staging system revisions (TNM edition updates) survival outcomes treatment effectiveness.

what: What is the Will Rogers Phenomenon?
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Rogers phenomenon describes situation : Stage Migration Occurs: Patients reclassified different disease stages due improved diagnostic methods revised staging criteria. Apparent Improvement: reclassification leads apparent improvements stage-specific outcomes without actual improvement individual patient outcomes. Statistical Paradox: stages appear improved survival rates, overall survival remains unchanged.

previous_headings: Introduction > What is the Will Rogers Phenomenon?
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Consider lung cancer staging TNM 7th 8th editions: Original System (7th Edition): patient 3.5cm tumor 2 positive lymph nodes classified Stage II New System (8th Edition): patient now classified Stage IIB due refined criteria patient better survival average Stage II patient worse survival average Stage IIB patient: Stage II survival improves (worst patients removed) Stage IIB survival improves (relatively good patients added) patient’s actual prognosis hasn’t changed

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Key Metrics: - Total patients: Overall sample size - Unchanged stage: Number patients remaining stage - Stage migration (%): Percentage patients changed stages - Upstaging (%): Percentage moved higher stages - Downstaging (%): Percentage moved lower stages - Chi-square: Statistical test association staging systems Interpretation: - Migration rates >20% indicate substantial staging changes - Significant chi-square suggests non-random migration patterns - Balance upstaging vs. downstaging reveals revision direction

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Shows patient distribution changes staging systems: Columns: - Stage: Individual stage categories - Original Count/%): Distribution original system - New Count/(%): Distribution new system - Change: Percentage point change Interpretation: - Large changes indicate major revision impact - Shifts toward early/late stages reveal staging drift - Balanced changes suggest refinement rather systematic bias

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Cross-tabulation showing exact patient flow stages: Features: - Rows: Original staging system - Columns: New staging system - Values: Patient counts percentages Interpretation: - Diagonal elements: Patients remaining equivalent stages - -diagonal elements: Migration patterns - High -diagonal values indicate significant reclassification

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Compares discriminative ability staging systems: Metrics: - C-index (Harrell’s): Measures discriminative ability (0.5 = random, 1.0 = perfect) - Log-rank test: Tests survival differences within system - AIC: Model quality measure (lower better) Interpretation: - C-index improvement >0.02 clinically meaningful - Lower AIC new system suggests better model fit - Stronger log-rank statistics indicate better stage separation

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 4: Interpret Results
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Identifies evidence phenomenon comparing survival within stages: Columns: - Stage: Original stage analyzed - Unchanged N: Patients remaining stage - Unchanged Median: Median survival unchanged patients - Migrated N: Patients moving different stages - Migrated Median: Median survival migrated patients - p-value: Test comparing unchanged vs. migrated survival Interpretation: - Significant p-values indicate Rogers phenomenon - Different median survivals groups confirm effect - Multiple significant stages suggest systematic migration bias

previous_headings: Using the Stage Migration Analysis Module > Step 5: Visual Interpretation
title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: alluvial/Sankey diagram visualizes patient flow: Elements: - Left axis: Original staging system - Right axis: New staging system - Flow bands: Patient migration pathways - Band thickness: Proportional patient numbers Interpretation: - Thick diagonal flows indicate stage stability - Curved flows show migration patterns - Complex flow patterns suggest major revision impact

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
text: Scenario: Evaluate impact TNM 8th edition lung cancer staging Analysis Steps: 1. Load dataset TNM 7th 8th edition stages 2. Set “tnm_7th” original stage, “tnm_8th” new stage 3. Use overall survival endpoint 4. Enable Rogers analysis Expected Findings: - Migration rate 25-40% lung cancer - Improved C-index 8th edition (typically +0.02 +0.05) - Evidence Rogers phenomenon Stage II/III patients - Better survival separation new system

title: Stage Migration Analysis: Understanding the Will Rogers Phenomenon
code: Stage migration analysis was performed using the ClinicoPath module in jamovi.  Patients were classified according to both [original system] and [new system]  staging criteria. Migration patterns were quantified using cross-tabulation  and chi-square tests. Prognostic performance was compared using Harrell's  C-index and log-rank tests. The Will Rogers phenomenon was assessed by  comparing survival between patients who remained in the same stage versus  those who migrated to different stages.

Evidence of the Will Rogers phenomenon was observed in [N] stages, with  significant survival differences between migrated and non-migrated patients  (p<0.05). Migration predominantly involved [describe pattern].

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Use case: Overall survival characteristics entire study population Steps: 1. Navigate Survival → ClinicoPath Survival → Single Arm Survival 2. Assign variables: - Time Elapsed: time variable - Outcome: event indicator - Outcome Level: Select level indicates event (usually “1”) 3. Configure options: - Cut Points: Time points survival estimates (e.g., “12, 36, 60” 1, 3, 5 years) - Time Type Output: Choose months years - Confidence Intervals: Enable 95% CI - Risk Table: Show numbers risk 4. Click Run Output includes: - Overall survival curve - Median survival time 95% CI - Survival rates specified time points - Natural language summary

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Use case: Compare survival different groups Steps: 1. Navigate Survival → ClinicoPath Survival → Survival Analysis 2. Assign variables: - Time Elapsed: time variable - Explanatory: Grouping variable (e.g., treatment, stage) - Outcome: event indicator - Outcome Level: Event level 3. Configure analysis: - Analysis Type: Choose overall, pairwise, combination - P-value Adjustment: Method multiple comparisons - Proportional Hazards: Enable Cox regression 4. Plotting options: - Risk Table: Show numbers risk - Censored Points: Mark censored observations - Confidence Intervals: Display CI bands - End Plot: Set maximum time plot Output includes: - Kaplan-Meier curves group - Log-rank test results - Cox regression hazard ratios - Pairwise comparisons (selected) - Survival tables group

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Use case: Find optimal cut-point continuous biomarker Steps: 1. Navigate Survival → ClinicoPath Survival → Survival Analysis Continuous Variable 2. Assign variables: - Time Elapsed: time variable - Continuous Explanatory: continuous predictor - Outcome: event indicator 3. Cut-point options: - Find Cut-point: Let algorithm find optimal threshold - Manual Cut-point: Specify threshold 4. Configure analysis similar group comparisons Output includes: - Optimal cut-point determination - Survival curves high/low groups - Hazard ratio dichotomized variable - ROC analysis cut-point validation

Assign variables: - Time Elapsed: time variable - Explanatory: Multiple explanatory variables - Outcome: event indicator 3. Model options: - Model Type: Choose Cox proportional hazards - Variable Selection: Manual automated selection - Interaction Terms: Include interactions needed Output includes: - Multivariable Cox regression table - Adjusted hazard ratios 95% CI - Model fit statistics - Adjusted survival curves

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Use case: Binary outcome analysis (case-control studies) Steps: 1. Navigate Survival → ClinicoPath Survival → Odds Ratio Table Plot 2. Assign variables: - Outcome: Binary outcome variable - Explanatory: Risk factors 3. Configure: - Reference Level: Choose reference category - Confidence Level: Usually 95% Output includes: - Odds ratio table - Forest plot - Chi-square test results

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Steep drops: High event rate specific times Flat portions: Low event rate (good prognosis periods) Wide confidence intervals: High uncertainty due small sample size Crossing curves: Proportional hazards assumption may violated

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Log-rank test: Compares overall survival distributions p < 0.05: Statistically significant difference groups Hazard Ratio > 1: Increased risk event Hazard Ratio < 1: Decreased risk event (protective factor)

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Median survival: Time 50% subjects experienced event 5-year survival rate: Percentage alive 5 years Confidence intervals: Uncertainty range around estimates Numbers risk: Sample size remaining time point

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Check data completeness: Missing time event data Validate event coding: Ensure consistent coding (0/1 /Yes) Review follow-times: Check unrealistic negative times Assess censoring pattern: High censoring rates may bias results

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: Sample size: Minimum 10 events per variable Cox regression Proportional hazards: Check assumption using Schoenfeld residuals Multiple comparisons: Adjust p-values testing multiple groups Clinical relevance: Statistical significance vs. clinical importance

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: CONSORT guidelines: Follow reporting standards survival studies Number risk tables: Always include survival plots Confidence intervals: Report alongside point estimates Effect sizes: Focus hazard ratios median survival differences

title: Using jsurvival in jamovi: Complete Workflow
text: “events observed”: Check event coding follow-time “Convergence failed”: May indicate separation small sample size “Proportional hazards violated”: Consider stratified Cox model Missing survival curves: Check variable assignments data types

text: alluvialSurvival() function ClinicoPath provides specialized visualization patient treatment pathways time, combining alluvial diagrams survival analysis. tool particularly valuable understanding patients move different disease stages treatments, ability incorporate survival outcomes. Unlike static cross-sectional analyses, alluvial survival plots reveal dynamic nature patient care, showing: - Disease progression stage migrations - Treatment sequence patterns - Patient flow different therapeutic interventions - Survival outcomes associated different pathways vignette demonstrates features alluvialSurvival function using real clinical datasets.

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: alluvialSurvival function requires longitudinal data specific structure:

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: Time Variable: Numeric time points (e.g., months, visits) Stage Variable: Disease stage time point (factor) Treatment Variable: Treatment received time point (factor) Patient ID: Unique identifier tracking individual patients (factor)

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: Survival Variable: Binary outcome variable (0 = alive, 1 = dead)

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: Longitudinal format: One row per patient per time point Minimum requirements: ≥5 patients, ≥2 time points missing values time patient ID variables

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
code: # Basic treatment pathway visualization alluvialSurvival(     data = treatment_pathways,     timeVar = "Time",     stageVar = "Disease_Stage",      treatmentVar = "Treatment",     patientId = "ID" )

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: alluvial plot shows: - Vertical strata: Categories time point - Flows: Patient transitions categories - Width: Proportional number patients - Colors: Clinical color scheme default

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival
text: function provides two carefully designed color palettes:
code: # Clinical color scheme (default) alluvialSurvival(     data = treatment_pathways,     timeVar = "Time",     stageVar = "Disease_Stage",     treatmentVar = "Treatment",      patientId = "ID",     colorScheme = "clinical" )  # Colorblind-safe palette alluvialSurvival(     data = treatment_pathways,     timeVar = "Time",     stageVar = "Disease_Stage",     treatmentVar = "Treatment",     patientId = "ID",      colorScheme = "colorblind" )

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival

code: # Show percentage of patients on right axis alluvialSurvival(     data = treatment_pathways,     timeVar = "Time",     stageVar = "Disease_Stage",     treatmentVar = "Treatment",     patientId = "ID",     showRightAxis = TRUE )

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival

code: # Add survival variable for statistics alluvialSurvival(     data = treatment_pathways,     timeVar = "Time",      stageVar = "Disease_Stage",     treatmentVar = "Treatment",     patientId = "ID",     survivalVar = "Survival_Status" )

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival

title: Treatment Pathway Visualization with alluvialSurvival

code: # Conceptual approach for multiple imputation # 1. Create multiple imputed datasets # 2. Analyze each dataset separately # 3. Pool results using Rubin's rules  # Example workflow (implementation details may vary): imputed_results <- list() for(i in 1:5) {  # 5 imputed datasets   imputed_results[[i]] <- survival(     data = imputed_data[[i]],     elapsedtime = time_months,     outcome = death,     outcomeLevel = "1",     explanatory = treatment   ) }  # Pool results (conceptual) pooled_hr <- mean(sapply(imputed_results, function(x) x$hazard_ratio)) pooled_se <- sqrt(mean(sapply(imputed_results, function(x) x$se^2)) +                    (1 + 1/5) * var(sapply(imputed_results, function(x) x$hazard_ratio)))

code: # Split data into training and validation sets set.seed(123) train_idx <- sample(nrow(biomarker_data), nrow(biomarker_data) * 0.7) train_data <- biomarker_data[train_idx, ] test_data <- biomarker_data[-train_idx, ]  # Find cut-point in training data train_cutpoint <- survivalcont(   data = train_data,   elapsedtime = time_months,   outcome = death,   outcomeLevel = "1",   contexpl = biomarker_value,   findcut = TRUE )  # Apply cut-point to test data test_data$biomarker_high <- ifelse(test_data$biomarker_value >= optimal_cutpoint,                                     "High", "Low")  validation_result <- survival(   data = test_data,   elapsedtime = time_months,   outcome = death,   outcomeLevel = "1",   explanatory = biomarker_high )

title: Advanced Survival Analysis with jsurvival
code: # Analyze survival at different landmark times landmark_times <- c(6, 12, 24)  # months landmark_results <- list()  for(t in landmark_times) {   # Create landmark dataset   landmark_data <- subset(original_data,                           time_months > t | (time_months <= t & death == 0))      # Adjust survival times   landmark_data$time_from_landmark <- pmax(0, landmark_data$time_months - t)      # Analyze   landmark_results[[paste0("Month_", t)]] <- survival(     data = landmark_data,     elapsedtime = time_from_landmark,     outcome = death,     outcomeLevel = "1",     explanatory = response_status,     uselandmark = TRUE,     landmark = t   ) }

title: Advanced Survival Analysis with jsurvival
code: # Conditional survival probabilities # Probability of surviving additional 2 years given survival to 1 year  # Patients alive at 12 months alive_12m <- subset(mydata, time_months > 12 | (time_months <= 12 & death == 0)) alive_12m$time_conditional <- pmax(0, alive_12m$time_months - 12)  conditional_survival <- singlearm(   data = alive_12m,   elapsedtime = time_conditional,   outcome = death,   outcomeLevel = "1",   cutp = "24",  # Additional 2 years   timetypeoutput = "months" )

title: Advanced Survival Analysis with jsurvival
code: # Hazard Ratio Interpretation: # HR = 0.50: 50% reduction in hazard (strong effect) # HR = 0.75: 25% reduction in hazard (moderate effect) # HR = 0.90: 10% reduction in hazard (small effect) # HR = 1.00: No effect # HR = 1.25: 25% increase in hazard (moderate harm) # HR = 2.00: 100% increase in hazard (strong harm)  # Number Needed to Treat (NNT) calculation survival_control <- 0.60  # 5-year survival in control survival_treatment <- 0.70  # 5-year survival in treatment absolute_benefit <- survival_treatment - survival_control nnt <- 1 / absolute_benefit  # Number needed to treat

title: Advanced Survival Analysis with jsurvival
code: # HR = 0.75 (95% CI: 0.60-0.95) # Interpretation: # - Point estimate suggests 25% reduction in hazard # - We can be 95% confident the true HR is between 0.60 and 0.95 # - Since CI excludes 1.0, result is statistically significant # - Minimum plausible benefit is 5% (HR=0.95) # - Maximum plausible benefit is 40% (HR=0.60)

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Let’s examine structure test data:
code: library(jsurvival) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  # Load example data data("groupedforest_comprehensive_data")  # Examine data structure str(groupedforest_comprehensive_data) # Preview the data head(groupedforest_comprehensive_data) %>%   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample of Comprehensive Grouped Forest Data")

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Let’s start basic analysis comparing treatment effects biomarker-positive biomarker-negative patients:
code: # Basic grouped forest plot by biomarker status result_biomarker <- groupedforest(   data = groupedforest_comprehensive_data,   time_var = "survival_months",   event_var = "death_event",   treatment_var = "treatment",   grouping_var = "biomarker_status",   show_statistics = TRUE,   show_overall = TRUE )  # The result object contains the analysis class(result_biomarker)

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Compare treatment effects early advanced tumor stages:
code: # Grouped analysis by tumor stage result_stage <- groupedforest(   data = groupedforest_comprehensive_data,   time_var = "survival_months",   event_var = "death_event",   treatment_var = "treatment",   grouping_var = "tumor_stage",   confidence_level = 0.95,   sort_by_hr = TRUE,   plot_title = "Treatment Effects by Tumor Stage" )

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Evaluate treatment effects across gender groups:
code: # Analysis by gender result_gender <- groupedforest(   data = groupedforest_comprehensive_data,   time_var = "survival_months",   event_var = "death_event",   treatment_var = "treatment",   grouping_var = "gender",   show_counts = TRUE,   plot_theme = "clinical" )

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Include covariates adjust confounding factors:
code: # Analysis with covariate adjustment result_adjusted <- groupedforest(   data = groupedforest_comprehensive_data,   time_var = "survival_months",   event_var = "death_event",   treatment_var = "treatment",   grouping_var = "biomarker_status",   covariates = c("age", "performance_status"),   reference_treatment = "Control",   show_statistics = TRUE )

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Test treatment--subgroup interactions:
code: # Test for interaction effects result_interaction <- groupedforest(   data = groupedforest_comprehensive_data,   time_var = "survival_months",   event_var = "death_event",   treatment_var = "treatment",   grouping_var = "tumor_stage",   interaction_test = TRUE,   show_overall = TRUE )

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Understanding impact subgroup sample sizes:
code: # Examine sample sizes by subgroup groupedforest_comprehensive_data %>%   group_by(biomarker_status, treatment) %>%   summarise(     n = n(),     events = sum(death_event),     event_rate = round(mean(death_event), 3),     .groups = 'drop'   ) %>%   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample Sizes and Event Rates by Subgroup")

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Demonstrate different confidence levels:
code: # Different confidence levels conf_levels <- c(0.80, 0.90, 0.95, 0.99)  for (conf_level in conf_levels) {   result <- groupedforest(     data = groupedforest_simple_data,     time_var = "time",     event_var = "event",      treatment_var = "treatment",     grouping_var = "subgroup",     confidence_level = conf_level,     plot_title = paste0(conf_level * 100, "% Confidence Intervals")   ) }

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Vertical line HR = 1: treatment effect Points left (HR < 1): Treatment reduces hazard (beneficial) Points right (HR > 1): Treatment increases hazard (harmful) Horizontal lines: Confidence intervals Wider intervals: Less precise estimates (smaller sample sizes)

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Confidence interval excludes 1: Statistically significant effect Confidence interval includes 1: Non-significant effect P-values: Individual subgroup significance tests

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Consistent effects: Similar HRs across subgroups Treatment interactions: Varying effects subgroups Precision medicine opportunities: Subgroups differential benefit

title: Grouped Hazard Forest Plots for Subgroup Analysis
text: Patient selection: Identify subgroups likely benefit Treatment recommendation: Consider subgroup-specific effects Future research: Hypothesis generation subsequent studies

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Automatic Variable Selection: Shrinks coefficients less important variables exactly zero Handles High-Dimensional Data: Works even p ≥ n (variables observations) Prevents Overfitting: Regularization improves model generalizability Clinical Interpretability: Produces sparse models selected key variables Cross-Validation: Optimal tuning parameter selection CV

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Lasso-Cox regression minimizes penalized partial log-likelihood: ℓ(β)−λ∑j=1p|βj|\ell(\beta) - \lambda \sum_{j=1}^p |\beta_j| : - ℓ(β)\ell(\beta) Cox partial log-likelihood - λ\lambda regularization parameter (tuning parameter) - ∑j=1p|βj|\sum_{j=1}^p |\beta_j| L1 penalty (Lasso)

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: lambda.min: Minimizes cross-validation error lambda.1se: Uses 1-standard-error rule (parsimonious) Typically 5-10 folds Balances model fit vs. complexity

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Measures discriminative ability Range: 0.5 (random) 1.0 (perfect) < 0.6: Poor discrimination 0.6-0.7: Fair discrimination 0.7-0.8: Good discrimination 0.8: Excellent discrimination

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Log-rank Test: Tests survival differences risk groups Hazard Ratio: Compares high vs. low risk groups Survival Curves: Visual assessment risk group separation

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: ’ll analyze lung cancer dataset identify key prognostic factors clinical variables.
code: # Load example data (would be provided in package) # For this example, we'll simulate realistic lung cancer data set.seed(123) n <- 180 lung_data <- data.frame(   # Survival outcome   follow_up_months = round(rexp(n, rate = 0.05) + runif(n, 0, 12), 1),   progression = factor(rbinom(n, 1, 0.6), levels = c(0, 1), labels = c("No", "Yes")),      # Clinical variables   age = round(rnorm(n, 65, 10)),   gender = factor(sample(c("Male", "Female"), n, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.6, 0.4))),   stage = factor(sample(c("I", "II", "III", "IV"), n, replace = TRUE,                          prob = c(0.2, 0.3, 0.3, 0.2))),   histology = factor(sample(c("Adenocarcinoma", "Squamous", "Other"), n, replace = TRUE,                             prob = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2))),   smoking_status = factor(sample(c("Never", "Former", "Current"), n, replace = TRUE,                                  prob = c(0.2, 0.5, 0.3))),   tumor_size_cm = round(rnorm(n, 4.5, 2.0), 1),   ecog_ps = factor(sample(0:2, n, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2))),      # Laboratory values   hemoglobin = round(rnorm(n, 12.5, 2.0), 1),   wbc_count = round(rnorm(n, 8.5, 3.0), 1),   creatinine = round(rnorm(n, 1.1, 0.3), 2) )  # Display basic characteristics str(lung_data)

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: example demonstrates Lasso-Cox high-dimensional genomic data p >> n.
code: # Simulate high-dimensional genomic data set.seed(456) n_patients <- 100 n_genes <- 500  # Create genomic dataset genomic_data <- data.frame(   # Survival outcome   survival_months = round(rweibull(n_patients, shape = 1.5, scale = 24), 1),   death = factor(rbinom(n_patients, 1, 0.4), levels = c(0, 1), labels = c("No", "Yes")),      # Clinical variables   age = round(rnorm(n_patients, 60, 12)),   stage = factor(sample(1:3, n_patients, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2)),                  levels = 1:3, labels = c("Early", "Intermediate", "Advanced")) )  # Add gene expression data (standardized) gene_matrix <- matrix(rnorm(n_patients * n_genes), nrow = n_patients, ncol = n_genes) colnames(gene_matrix) <- paste0("GENE_", sprintf("%03d", 1:n_genes))  # Combine clinical and genomic data genomic_data <- cbind(genomic_data, gene_matrix)  cat("Dataset dimensions:", nrow(genomic_data), "patients ×", ncol(genomic_data), "variables") cat("\nNumber of genes:", n_genes) cat("\nEvents:", sum(genomic_data$death == "Yes"), "deaths")

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Problem: Lasso selects zero variables (λ large) Solutions:
code: # Try lambda.min instead of lambda.1se result <- lassocox(..., lambda = "lambda.min")  # Reduce regularization strength manually result <- lassocox(..., alpha = 0.5)  # Elastic net (if supported)  # Check for high correlation among predictors cor_matrix <- cor(predictors, use = "complete.obs") high_cor <- which(abs(cor_matrix) > 0.9 & cor_matrix != 1, arr.ind = TRUE)

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Problem: Model selects many variables (underfitting) Solutions:
code: # Use lambda.1se for more regularization result <- lassocox(..., lambda = "lambda.1se")  # Increase number of CV folds result <- lassocox(..., nfolds = 10)  # Pre-filter variables by univariate significance univariate_p <- sapply(predictors, function(x) {   cox_fit <- coxph(Surv(time, event) ~ x)   summary(cox_fit)$coefficients[, "Pr(>|z|)"] }) significant_vars <- names(univariate_p)[univariate_p < 0.1]

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Problem: Low C-index poor risk stratification Solutions:
code: # Check data quality summary(survival_data) plot(survfit(Surv(time, event) ~ 1))  # Overall survival curve  # Ensure adequate events table(survival_data$event)  # Need at least 5-10 events per variable  # Consider interaction terms clinical_data$age_stage_interaction <- clinical_data$age * as.numeric(clinical_data$stage)  # Try different time scales clinical_data$log_time <- log(clinical_data$time + 1)

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Problem: Algorithm doesn’t converge Solutions:
code: # Standardize variables result <- lassocox(..., standardize = TRUE)  # Remove extreme outliers Q1 <- quantile(continuous_var, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) Q3 <- quantile(continuous_var, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) IQR <- Q3 - Q1 outliers <- which(continuous_var < (Q1 - 1.5*IQR) | continuous_var > (Q3 + 1.5*IQR))  # Check for perfect separation table(survival_data$event, survival_data$categorical_predictor)

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
text: Events per Variable: Aim 5-10 events per candidate variable Total Sample Size: Consider expected censoring rate Effect Size: Larger effects require smaller samples Multiple Testing: Account variable selection process

title: Lasso-Cox Regression for Variable Selection in Survival Analysis
code: # Pre-selection strategies: # 1. Clinical relevance clinical_vars <- c("age", "stage", "grade", "treatment")  # 2. Univariate screening (liberal p-value) univariate_screen <- function(data, time_var, event_var, predictors, p_threshold = 0.2) {   significant_vars <- c()   for (var in predictors) {     formula <- as.formula(paste("Surv(", time_var, ",", event_var, ") ~", var))     cox_fit <- coxph(formula, data = data)     p_value <- summary(cox_fit)$coefficients[, "Pr(>|z|)"]     if (p_value < p_threshold) {       significant_vars <- c(significant_vars, var)     }   }   return(significant_vars) }  # 3. Correlation filtering remove_high_correlation <- function(data, threshold = 0.9) {   cor_matrix <- cor(data, use = "complete.obs")   high_cor <- findCorrelation(cor_matrix, cutoff = threshold)   return(names(data)[-high_cor]) }

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: package includes comprehensive test datasets different cancer types:
code: # Load lung cancer staging data load("stagemigration_lung_cancer.rda")  # Examine the data structure head(lung_cancer_data) str(lung_cancer_data)  # Check staging distribution table(lung_cancer_data$old_stage, lung_cancer_data$new_stage)

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: dataset include: Old staging variable: Original staging system (e.g., TNM 7th edition) New staging variable: Proposed staging system (e.g., TNM 8th edition) Survival time: Time event censoring (months recommended) Event indicator: Death event occurrence (1 = event, 0 = censored) Patient characteristics: Age, sex, histology, performance status, etc.

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: Start basic analysis understand migration patterns:
code: # Basic stage migration analysis basic_result <- stagemigration(   data = lung_cancer_data,   oldStage = "old_stage",   newStage = "new_stage",   survivalTime = "survival_time",   event = "event",   eventLevel = "1",   analysisType = "basic" )  # View migration matrix print(basic_result$results$migrationMatrix)  # View stage-specific survival statistics print(basic_result$results$stageSummary)

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: migration matrix shows patients move staging systems:
code: # Calculate migration statistics migration_stats <- lung_cancer_data %>%   mutate(     migration_type = case_when(       old_stage == new_stage ~ "No Change",       as.numeric(old_stage) < as.numeric(new_stage) ~ "Upstaging",       as.numeric(old_stage) > as.numeric(new_stage) ~ "Downstaging"     )   ) %>%   count(migration_type) %>%   mutate(percentage = round(n / sum(n) * 100, 1))  print(migration_stats)

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: publication-quality staging validation, use standard analysis:
code: # Standard staging validation standard_result <- stagemigration(   data = lung_cancer_data,   oldStage = "old_stage",   newStage = "new_stage",   survivalTime = "survival_time",   event = "event",   eventLevel = "1",   analysisType = "standard",      # Advanced metrics   calculateNRI = TRUE,   calculateIDI = TRUE,   performROCAnalysis = TRUE,   performDCA = TRUE,      # Validation   performBootstrap = TRUE,   bootstrapReps = 1000,      # Cancer-specific guidance   cancerType = "lung",      # Visualization   showMigrationHeatmap = TRUE,   showROCComparison = TRUE,   showForestPlot = TRUE )  # View key results print(standard_result$results$concordanceComparison) print(standard_result$results$nriResults) print(standard_result$results$clinicalInterpretation)

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: NRI quantifies improvement risk classification:
code: # Interpret NRI results nri_results <- standard_result$results$nriResults$asDF  # NRI > 0.20 (20%) is considered clinically significant # NRI > 0.60 (60%) is considered substantial improvement for (i in 1:nrow(nri_results)) {   time_point <- nri_results$TimePoint[i]   nri_value <- nri_results$NRI[i]      interpretation <- case_when(     nri_value > 0.60 ~ "Substantial improvement",     nri_value > 0.20 ~ "Clinically significant improvement",     nri_value > 0.10 ~ "Modest improvement",     nri_value > 0.00 ~ "Minimal improvement",     TRUE ~ "No improvement or worsening"   )      cat(sprintf("Time %s months: NRI = %.3f (%s)\n",                time_point, nri_value, interpretation)) }

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
text: IDI measures improvement predicted probabilities:
code: # Interpret IDI results idi_results <- standard_result$results$idiResults$asDF  # IDI > 0.02 is considered clinically meaningful # IDI > 0.05 is considered substantial idi_value <- idi_results$IDI[1]  idi_interpretation <- case_when(   idi_value > 0.05 ~ "Substantial improvement in risk prediction",   idi_value > 0.02 ~ "Clinically meaningful improvement",   idi_value > 0.01 ~ "Modest improvement",   idi_value > 0.00 ~ "Minimal improvement",   TRUE ~ "No improvement" )  cat(sprintf("IDI = %.4f (%s)\n", idi_value, idi_interpretation))

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
code:
# Framework for interpreting staging validation results interpret_staging_validation <- function(result, cancer_type = "general") {      # Extract key metrics   concordance <- result$results$concordanceComparison$asDF   nri <- result$results$nriResults$asDF   clinical_interp <- result$results$clinicalInterpretation$asDF      # C-index interpretation   c_index_old <- concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "Old Staging"]   c_index_new <- concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "New Staging"]   c_index_diff <- c_index_new - c_index_old      # NRI interpretation (using 24-month if available)   nri_24 <- nri$NRI[nri$TimePoint == "24"]   if (length(nri_24) == 0) nri_24 <- nri$NRI[1]      # Clinical decision framework   cat("=== STAGING VALIDATION INTERPRETATION ===

")      # C-index assessment   cat("1. DISCRIMINATION (C-INDEX):
")   cat(sprintf("   Old staging C-index: %.3f
", c_index_old))   cat(sprintf("   New staging C-index: %.3f
", c_index_new))   cat(sprintf("   Improvement: %.4f
", c_index_diff))      if (c_index_diff >= 0.02) {     cat("   ✓ CLINICALLY SIGNIFICANT improvement
")   } else if (c_index_diff > 0.01) {     cat("   ⚠ MODEST improvement (borderline significance)
")   } else if (c_index_diff > 0.005) {     cat("   ⚠ MINIMAL improvement
")   } else {     cat("   ✗ NO meaningful improvement
")   }      cat("
2. RECLASSIFICATION (NRI):
")   cat(sprintf("   24-month NRI: %.3f
", nri_24))      if (nri_24 > 0.20) {     cat("   ✓ CLINICALLY SIGNIFICANT reclassification improvement
")   } else if (nri_24 > 0.10) {     cat("   ⚠ MODEST reclassification improvement
")   } else if (nri_24 > 0.05) {     cat("   ⚠ MINIMAL reclassification improvement
")   } else {     cat("   ✗ NO meaningful reclassification improvement
")   }      # Overall recommendation   cat("
3. OVERALL RECOMMENDATION:
")      if (c_index_diff >= 0.02 && nri_24 > 0.20) {     cat("   ✓ STRONGLY RECOMMEND adopting new staging system
")     cat("   • Both discrimination and reclassification show significant improvement
")     cat("   • Clinical benefit is well-established
")   } else if (c_index_diff >= 0.015 || nri_24 > 0.15) {     cat("   ⚠ CONSIDER adopting new staging system
")     cat("   • Moderate improvement shown
")     cat("   • Additional validation recommended
")   } else {     cat("   ✗ INSUFFICIENT evidence for adoption
")     cat("   • Improvements are below clinical significance thresholds
")     cat("   • Consider larger sample size or different approach
")   }      cat("
4. IMPLEMENTATION CONSIDERATIONS:
")   cat("   • Training requirements for new staging system
")   cat("   • Cost-benefit analysis of system change
")   cat("   • Integration with existing clinical workflows
")   cat("   • External validation in independent cohorts
")      return(invisible(list(     c_index_improvement = c_index_diff,     nri_improvement = nri_24,     recommendation = ifelse(c_index_diff >= 0.02 && nri_24 > 0.20, "Adopt",                             ifelse(c_index_diff >= 0.015 || nri_24 > 0.15, "Consider", "Insufficient"))   ))) }  # Apply interpretation framework interpretation <- interpret_staging_validation(lung_result, "lung")

# Analyze different sample sizes sample_sizes <- c(100, 200, 500, 1000)  sample_size_results <- list()  for (n in sample_sizes) {      # Create subsample   subsample <- lung_cancer_data %>%      slice_sample(n = n) %>%     mutate(event = as.numeric(event))      # Run analysis   result <- stagemigration(     data = subsample,     oldStage = "old_stage",     newStage = "new_stage",     survivalTime = "survival_time",     event = "event",     eventLevel = "1",     analysisType = "standard",     calculateNRI = TRUE,     calculateIDI = TRUE,     cancerType = "lung",     performBootstrap = FALSE  # Skip for speed   )      # Extract key metrics   concordance <- result$results$concordanceComparison$asDF   c_index_diff <- concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "New Staging"] -                    concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "Old Staging"]      nri_result <- result$results$nriResults$asDF   nri_24 <- nri_result$NRI[nri_result$TimePoint == "24"]   if (length(nri_24) == 0) nri_24 <- nri_result$NRI[1]      sample_size_results[[as.character(n)]] <- list(     n = n,     c_index_improvement = c_index_diff,     nri_improvement = nri_24,     events = sum(subsample$event),     event_rate = mean(subsample$event)   ) }  # Summarize sample size effects sample_size_summary <- do.call(rbind, lapply(sample_size_results, function(x) {   data.frame(     SampleSize = x$n,     Events = x$events,     EventRate = round(x$event_rate, 3),     CIndexImprovement = round(x$c_index_improvement, 4),     NRIImprovement = round(x$nri_improvement, 3)   ) }))  print(sample_size_summary)  # Recommendations for sample size cat("
=== SAMPLE SIZE RECOMMENDATIONS ===
") cat("• Minimum 200 patients for basic analysis
") cat("• Minimum 500 patients for reliable NRI/IDI estimation
") cat("• Minimum 1000 patients for comprehensive validation
") cat("• At least 100 events for stable results
") cat("• Consider power analysis for specific effect sizes
")

# Complete publication-ready analysis publication_result <- stagemigration(   data = lung_cancer_data,   oldStage = "old_stage",   newStage = "new_stage",   survivalTime = "survival_time",   event = "event",   eventLevel = "1",   analysisType = "publication",      # Complete statistical analysis   calculateNRI = TRUE,   calculateIDI = TRUE,   performROCAnalysis = TRUE,   performDCA = TRUE,   performCalibration = TRUE,      # Validation   performBootstrap = TRUE,   bootstrapReps = 2000,   useOptimismCorrection = TRUE,   performCrossValidation = TRUE,   cvFolds = 10,      # Model comparison   performLikelihoodTests = TRUE,   calculatePseudoR2 = TRUE,   performHomogeneityTests = TRUE,   performTrendTests = TRUE,   showWillRogersAnalysis = TRUE,      # Clinical assessment   clinicalSignificanceThreshold = 0.02,   nriClinicalThreshold = 0.20,   cancerType = "lung",      # Time points   nriTimePoints = "6, 12, 18, 24, 36, 60",   rocTimePoints = "6, 12, 18, 24, 36, 60",      # Comprehensive outputs   showClinicalInterpretation = TRUE,   generateExecutiveSummary = TRUE,   showStatisticalSummary = TRUE,   showMethodologyNotes = TRUE,   includeEffectSizes = TRUE,      # Visualizations   showMigrationHeatmap = TRUE,   showROCComparison = TRUE,   showCalibrationPlots = TRUE,   showDecisionCurves = TRUE,   showForestPlot = TRUE,      # Confidence intervals   showConfidenceIntervals = TRUE,   confidenceLevel = 0.95 )  # Generate manuscript tables cat("=== TABLE 1: PATIENT CHARACTERISTICS ===
") # This would typically be generated separately with tableone or similar  cat("
=== TABLE 2: STAGING MIGRATION MATRIX ===
") print(publication_result$results$migrationMatrix)  cat("
=== TABLE 3: DISCRIMINATION COMPARISON ===
") print(publication_result$results$concordanceComparison)  cat("

title: Advanced TNM Stage Migration Analysis: A Comprehensive Guide
code:
# Template for statistical reporting generate_methods_text <- function(result, cancer_type) {      cat("=== METHODS SECTION TEXT ===

")      cat("Statistical Analysis:
")   cat("Stage migration analysis was performed using the ClinicoPath package in R. ")   cat("We compared the discriminative ability of the original and new staging systems ")   cat("using Harrell's C-index with 95% confidence intervals. Net Reclassification ")   cat("Improvement (NRI) was calculated at 6, 12, 24, 36, and 60 months to quantify ")   cat("improvement in risk classification. Integrated Discrimination Improvement (IDI) ")   cat("was used to assess overall improvement in predicted survival probabilities.

")      cat("Time-dependent receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis was performed ")   cat("to evaluate discriminative ability over time. Decision curve analysis (DCA) ")   cat("was used to assess the clinical utility of each staging system across different ")   cat("decision thresholds. Bootstrap validation with 2000 repetitions was performed ")   cat("to assess internal validity and apply optimism correction.

")      cat("Clinical significance was defined as C-index improvement ≥0.02 and NRI >20%. ")   cat("Likelihood ratio tests were used to compare nested models. All statistical ")   cat("tests were two-sided with significance level α=0.05.

")      cat("=== RESULTS SECTION TEXT ===

")      # Extract key results   concordance <- result$results$concordanceComparison$asDF   nri <- result$results$nriResults$asDF      c_index_old <- concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "Old Staging"]   c_index_new <- concordance$C_Index[concordance$Model == "New Staging"]   c_index_diff <- c_index_new - c_index_old      nri_24 <- nri$NRI[nri$TimePoint == "24"]   if (length(nri_24) == 0) nri_24 <- nri$NRI[1]      cat(sprintf("The original staging system achieved a C-index of %.3f (95%% CI: %.3f-%.3f), ",               c_index_old,                concordance$CI_Lower[concordance$Model == "Old Staging"],               concordance$CI_Upper[concordance$Model == "Old Staging"]))      cat(sprintf("while the new staging system achieved a C-index of %.3f (95%% CI: %.3f-%.3f), ",               c_index_new,               concordance$CI_Lower[concordance$Model == "New Staging"],               concordance$CI_Upper[concordance$Model == "New Staging"]))      cat(sprintf("representing an improvement of %.4f (p<0.001).

", c_index_diff))      cat(sprintf("The 24-month Net Reclassification Improvement was %.3f (95%% CI: %.3f-%.3f), ",               nri_24,               nri$NRI_CI_Lower[nri$TimePoint == "24"],               nri$NRI_CI_Upper[nri$TimePoint == "24"]))      if (nri_24 > 0.20) {     cat("indicating clinically significant improvement in risk classification.

")   } else {     cat("indicating modest improvement in risk classification.

")   }      cat("Bootstrap validation with optimism correction confirmed the stability of these results.

")      return(invisible(NULL)) }  # Generate methods and results text generate_methods_text(publication_result, "lung")

# Check for missing data check_missing_data <- function(data) {   missing_summary <- data %>%     summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>%     gather(variable, missing_count) %>%     mutate(missing_percent = round(missing_count / nrow(data) * 100, 1)) %>%     filter(missing_count > 0) %>%     arrange(desc(missing_count))      if (nrow(missing_summary) > 0) {     cat("Missing data detected:
")     print(missing_summary)          # Recommendations     cat("
Recommendations:
")     cat("• Consider multiple imputation for <10% missing
")     cat("• Use complete case analysis for >10% missing
")     cat("• Assess missingness pattern (MCAR, MAR, MNAR)
")   } else {     cat("No missing data detected
")   }      return(missing_summary) }  # Check example data missing_summary <- check_missing_data(lung_cancer_data)

code:
# Load problematic data load("stagemigration_problematic.rda")  # Analyze problematic migration patterns problematic_result <- stagemigration(   data = problematic_data,   oldStage = "old_stage",   newStage = "new_stage",   survivalTime = "survival_time",   event = "event",   eventLevel = "1",   analysisType = "basic",      # Conservative settings   confidenceLevel = 0.90,   clinicalSignificanceThreshold = 0.03,   nriClinicalThreshold = 0.30,      # Focus on basic metrics   calculateNRI = TRUE,   performBootstrap = FALSE,   showClinicalInterpretation = TRUE )  # Analyze migration patterns migration_analysis <- problematic_data %>%   count(old_stage, new_stage) %>%   group_by(old_stage) %>%   mutate(     total_in_old_stage = sum(n),     migration_rate = n / total_in_old_stage,     migration_type = case_when(       old_stage == new_stage ~ "No Change",       as.numeric(old_stage) < as.numeric(new_stage) ~ "Upstaging",       as.numeric(old_stage) > as.numeric(new_stage) ~ "Downstaging"     )   )  print(migration_analysis)  # Identify problematic patterns problematic_patterns <- migration_analysis %>%   filter(migration_rate > 0.5, migration_type != "No Change")  if (nrow(problematic_patterns) > 0) {   cat("WARNING: Problematic migration patterns detected:
")   print(problematic_patterns)   cat("
Consider:
")   cat("• Reviewing staging criteria
")   cat("• Checking for systematic biases
")   cat("• Validating in independent cohort
") }

title: Data Preparation for Survival Analysis
code: library(lubridate)  # Example data with dates clinical_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = 1:100,   diagnosis_date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + sample(0:365, 100, replace = TRUE),   death_date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + sample(200:1000, 100, replace = TRUE),   last_followup_date = as.Date("2023-12-31") )  # Calculate time to death or censoring clinical_data$death_occurred <- !is.na(clinical_data$death_date) clinical_data$event_date <- ifelse(clinical_data$death_occurred,                                    clinical_data$death_date,                                    clinical_data$last_followup_date) clinical_data$event_date <- as.Date(clinical_data$event_date, origin = "1970-01-01")  # Time in months clinical_data$time_months <- as.numeric(   difftime(clinical_data$event_date, clinical_data$diagnosis_date, units = "days") ) / 30.44  # Average days per month  # Time in years clinical_data$time_years <- as.numeric(   difftime(clinical_data$event_date, clinical_data$diagnosis_date, units = "days") ) / 365.25  # Accounting for leap years

code: # Function to perform comprehensive data quality checks check_survival_data <- function(data, time_var, event_var) {      checks <- list()      # 1. Missing values   checks$missing_time <- sum(is.na(data[[time_var]]))   checks$missing_event <- sum(is.na(data[[event_var]]))      # 2. Negative or zero times   checks$negative_times <- sum(data[[time_var]] <= 0, na.rm = TRUE)      # 3. Event indicator values   event_values <- unique(data[[event_var]])   checks$valid_events <- all(event_values %in% c(0, 1, NA))   checks$event_table <- table(data[[event_var]], useNA = "always")      # 4. Extreme values   checks$extreme_times <- list(     max_time = max(data[[time_var]], na.rm = TRUE),     min_time = min(data[[time_var]], na.rm = TRUE),     outliers = sum(data[[time_var]] > quantile(data[[time_var]], 0.99, na.rm = TRUE), na.rm = TRUE)   )      # 5. Event rate   checks$event_rate <- mean(data[[event_var]], na.rm = TRUE)      return(checks) }  # Run checks data_quality <- check_survival_data(clinical_data, "time_months", "death_binary") print(data_quality)

title: Data Preparation for Survival Analysis
code: # Identify potential outliers in survival times Q1 <- quantile(clinical_data$time_months, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE) Q3 <- quantile(clinical_data$time_months, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) IQR <- Q3 - Q1  # Define outliers using 1.5 * IQR rule lower_bound <- Q1 - 1.5 * IQR upper_bound <- Q3 + 1.5 * IQR  outliers <- clinical_data$time_months < lower_bound | clinical_data$time_months > upper_bound print(paste("Found", sum(outliers, na.rm = TRUE), "potential outliers"))  # Review outliers if(sum(outliers, na.rm = TRUE) > 0) {   outlier_data <- clinical_data[outliers & !is.na(outliers),                                 c("patient_id", "time_months", "death_binary")]   print(outlier_data) }

title: Data Preparation for Survival Analysis
code: # Assess missing data patterns library(VIM)  # Visualization and Imputation of Missing values  # Create missingness indicator clinical_data$time_missing <- is.na(clinical_data$time_months) clinical_data$event_missing <- is.na(clinical_data$death_binary)  # Missing data summary missing_summary <- clinical_data %>%   summarise(     n_total = n(),     time_missing = sum(time_missing),     event_missing = sum(event_missing),     both_missing = sum(time_missing & event_missing),     complete_cases = sum(!time_missing & !event_missing)   )  print(missing_summary)

code: # For missing death dates, censor at last known follow-up clinical_data$time_months_imputed <- clinical_data$time_months clinical_data$death_binary_imputed <- clinical_data$death_binary  # If death status missing but last follow-up available, assume alive missing_death <- is.na(clinical_data$death_binary) & !is.na(clinical_data$last_followup_date) if(any(missing_death)) {   clinical_data$death_binary_imputed[missing_death] <- 0   clinical_data$time_months_imputed[missing_death] <-      as.numeric(difftime(clinical_data$last_followup_date[missing_death],                        clinical_data$diagnosis_date[missing_death],                         units = "days")) / 30.44 }
